content: The "Renewable Energy Incentive Act" extends grants for specified energy property in lieu of tax credits until 2013 and expands grants for specified energy property in lieu of tax credits. The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 allows grants for certain governmental units and cooperative electric companies, with specific amendments to subsection (g) of section 1603. The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 allows grants for certain governmental units and cooperative electric companies, with amendments to section 1603(g) regarding property financed with CREBs or Tax-Exempt Bonds. The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 allows grants for cooperative electric companies, with amendments to section 501(c) regarding the treatment of grants received under section 1603. The amendments made by the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 apply to property placed in service after the enactment date of the Act. SEC. 4. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new clause for qualified solar manufacturing project property, which includes tangible personal property used in the production process. This property is eligible for a grant under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 applies to periods after the enactment of the Act, with rules similar to section 48(m) of the Code. Grants for property placed in service after the Act's enactment are also affected. SEC. 5. CREDIT FOR HIGH SOLARITY DISTURBED PRIVATE LAND CONSOLIDATION. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section for a credit related to high solarity disturbed private land consolidation. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a credit for purchasing high solarity disturbed private land to consolidate for solar energy production. The credit is 30% of amounts paid to purchase more than 2 sections of contiguous land suitable for solar energy production. High solarity disturbed private land is defined as real property in the US with less than 100 contiguous acres acquired from a private person, located in areas with a solar resource of 7 kwh per square. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a credit for purchasing high solarity disturbed private land for solar energy production. The criteria include having a solar resource of 7 kwh per square meter per year or higher, being outside sensitive environmental or urban areas, previously disturbed by development or industrial use, and used for generating solar electricity within 5 years of purchase. The basis of the property is reduced by the amount of the credit determined. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a credit for purchasing high solarity disturbed private land for solar energy production. Rules similar to section 50(b) apply for property used by tax-exempt persons. The Secretary can recapture the credit if the property is not used for solar energy production within 5 years.
